input: (In this article, we provide a comparative analysis of two technologies for the cultivation of corn for grain in the Zhambyl region-the existing and resource-saving. The studied technologies of cultivation of corn for grain have fundamental differences. The existing technology aims to obtain the highest possible yields by using an unlimited amount of water resources, fertilizers, and plant protection products. As a result, it led to the deterioration of the reclamation and ecological condition of irrigated lands. Resource-saving technology, in comparison with the existing one, implies a reduction in the use of water resources, fertilizers, plant protection products and their use, taking into account the needs of agricultural crops. The use of biostimulators and bioameliorants, prepared on the basis of local raw materials, provides an increase in soil fertility and desalinization of the soil in the rhizosphere zone, which contributes to the normal growth and development of the cultivated crop.)
output: {'Planting or Production Trial':['A comparative analysis was conducted between existing and resource-saving technologies for the cultivation of corn for grain in the Zhambyl region. The existing technology, which uses an unlimited amount of resources, has led to ecological degradation, whereas the resource-saving technology reduces resource use and incorporates biostimulators and bioameliorants to enhance soil fertility and support sustainable crop growth.']}

input: (Field experiments were conducted in 2017 and 2018 at two different locations, one at the Xinxiang Comprehensive Experimental Station of the Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences (35°18'N, 113°54'E) (Xinxiang Station) and the other at the Experimental Demonstration Base of the Western Agricultural Research Center in Changji, Xinjiang Province (44°26N, 87°34'E) (ChangjiStation). The planting area for each hybrid was 600 m² with a 60 m row spacing and the planting density was 6.7 plants/m². Local cultivation and management measurements were adopted. Treatments were harvested on five different dates separated by intervals of 10-15 d: October 6, October 16, October 27, November 10, and November 25. input: (Roots, leaves and spikelets in the booting and seedling stages and stems in booting stage were sampled from wheat cultivar Yangmai 158 for spatio-temporal expression analysis. Seedlings at the six-leaf stage were treated with Agrobacterium tumefaciens strain EHA105 for 1.5 h following a simplified method for Agrobacterium-mediated transformation of Arabidopsis thaliana (Clough and Bent,1998). The leaves of the seedlings were cut into pieces at 1,6 and 12 h, respectively, and were collected randomly. Seedlings from the two-leaf stage of wheat cultivar Jingdong 8, which is susceptible to powdery mildew fungus, were inoculated with Blumeria graminis f. sp. tritici (Bgt) isolate E09, and leaves were sampled at 12 h after the inoculation.)

The treatments included dipping in Deoxynivalenol solution and inoculation with Agrobacterium tumefaciens and Blumeria graminis. Samples were collected at multiple time points for spatio-temporal expression analysis.']}

instruction: Identify the main event type and provide a summary of the event from the given text. The result should be presented in a dictionary format where the key is the event type and the value is a summary of the event.
input: (The study was conducted in a greenhouse at the Department of Plant Production, Faculty of Agricultural Sciences, in Botucatu-SP. During the experimental period, the temperature in the greenhouse was maintained at 23 ± 2°C. Plastic pots of 8 L were used, filled with soil from the top layer (0-0.20 m) of a Dystroferric Red Latosol, sieved through a 4 mm mesh. The chemical analysis of the soil, conducted according to the methodology proposed by Raij and Quaggio (1983), showed the following values: pH in CaCl2 4.4; 18 g dm-3 M.O.; 14 g dm-3 Presina? 43, 0.50, 8.0, and 4.0 mmol. dm-3 of H+Al, K, Ca, and Mg, respectively, and base saturation of 23%. A sample of the soil was conditioned in volumetric rings of 100 cm³ to determine water retention at tensions of -0.3, -1.0, and -15.0 atm, using the Richards pressure chamber method (EMBRAPA, 1997). The need for liming was calculated according to Raij et al. (1997), aiming to raise the base saturation to 60%. After the incorporation of limestone, the soil was moistened to 80% of field capacity and maintained at this moisture level for twenty days. Along with the limestone, 50 mg dm-3 N, 200 mg dm-3 P, and 150 mg dm-3 K were incorporated, in the forms of urea, simple superphosphate, and potassium chloride, respectively. The experimental design was a randomized block in a 4x3 factorial scheme, with four repetitions. Four species of grasses were evaluated: Avena strigosa Sckreb, Pennisetum glaucum (L.) R. Brown cv. ADR300, Sorghum bicolor L. Moench., and Sorghum bicolor subspecies bicolor race guinea, and three soil water potentials: -0.3 atm (field capacity), -1.0 atm (initial water deficit), and -15.0 atm (permanent wilting point). The approximate lethal water potential (Ya) for pearl millet (Pennisetum glaucum) is -3 atm (PIMENTEL, 2004) and for grain sorghum (Sorghum bicolor) is -3.5 atm (BOYER, 1978, cited by PIMENTEL 2004). However, the potentials used in this study were chosen specifically to compare the development of the species under extreme conditions of water availability. Ten seeds per pot were sown, leaving six seedlings at the time of thinning, fifteen days after emergence. At 25 days after emergence, top dressing was carried out, applying 50 mg N dm-³ (urea) and 50 mg K dm-³ (KCl) in solution form. The soil moisture of all treatments was maintained close to field capacity (-0.3 atm) until fifteen days after plant emergence. The three water potentials were imposed from this date and remained until the end of the experiment. The soil water content was controlled by daily weighing of the pots and replenishing the amount of water lost. In order to refine the irrigation management and consequent control of soil water, extra pots with plants of pearl millet, black oat, grain sorghum, and guinea sorghum at different stages were conducted.)
output: {'Planting or Production Trial':['A greenhouse study was conducted at the Department of Plant Production, Faculty of Agricultural Sciences, in Botucatu-SP to evaluate the growth of four grass species under three different soil water potentials. The study involved detailed soil preparation, controlled environmental conditions, and systematic application of nutrients and water to assess the plants' responses to varying water availability.']}

input: (Pearl millet is a good option to be cropped during offseason by showing high yield potential, even being more sensitive to water deficit. Grain sorghum and guinea sorghum are also good options, particularly by showing an abundant root system, which possibly gives them a certain tolerance to low water availability conditions. The black oat, even with high tolerance to water stress (tolerance conferred by the highest percentage of fine roots), seems to be much affected by higher temperatures, common to these regions.)
output: {'Planting or Production Trial':['The study assessed the suitability of pearl millet, grain sorghum, and guinea sorghum as offseason crops under conditions of water deficit. Pearl millet showed high yield potential despite its sensitivity to water scarcity, while both sorghum varieties demonstrated robust root systems that likely contribute to their drought tolerance. Black oat, although highly tolerant to water stress, was negatively impacted by higher temperatures.']}

input: (This research was conducted in the experimental area and in the Central Seed Laboratory of the Agriculture Department at the Federal University of Lavras (UFLA), in Lavras, MG. Seeds from six different maize lineages (30, 44, 54, 63, 64, and 90) that have different levels of tolerance to high temperatures were used. For the physiological assessment of maize seeds in relation to different temperatures during germination, the following tests were performed: Water content was determined by the oven method at 105°C for 24h (Brazil, 2009). Results are expressed as mean percentage (wet basis). A germination test was performed at five different temperatures (25°, 30°, 35°, 40°, and 45°℃), and for each temperature the test was conducted with four replications of 50 seeds. The seeds were sown between paper moistened with distilled water at a ratio of 2.5-times the weight of the dry paper. The rolls were stored in plastic bags and kept in B.O.D chambers each regulated at one of the five temperatures. Normal seedling evaluations were performed 4, 7, and 14 days after planting. Normal seedlings were considered to have a standard primary root length of 0.5cm. Results are expressed as mean percentage.)
output: {'Planting or Production Trial':['The research involved a physiological assessment of maize seeds from six different lineages at varying temperatures during germination. The study was conducted at the Central Seed Laboratory of the Agriculture Department at the Federal University of Lavras. Various tests, including water content and germination at temperatures ranging from 25° to 45°C, were performed to evaluate the seeds' tolerance to high temperatures.']}

instruction: Identify the main event type and provide a summary of the event from the given text. The result should be presented in a dictionary format where the key is the event type and the value is a summary of the event.
input: (The experiment was carried out at the experimental farm of the School of Animal Science, Henan University of Science and Technology, Luoyang, China. Seven hundred and twenty Arbor Acres broilers were sourced specifically for the experiment and housed in four tier caging system with 12 birds per cage and six cages per treatment. The birds were caged from hatch to 18 d with 50:50 males to females in each treatment. The cage floor space was 80x100 cm. Light was provided for 20 h/d with controlled ventilation and humidity at 75%. Temperature was controlled between 32-27°C, as per the breeder guidelines. Birds were vaccinated against Newcastle Disease and Infectious Bronchitis at 7 d of age. Between days 15 and 18, FI was measured on a per-pen basis and excreta was collected for AME determination. At d18 of the study birds were killed by electrical stunning. A section of ileum was removed between the Meckel's diverticulum and the ileo-caecal junction. A 50 ml syringe full of room-temperature deionised water was inserted into one end of the ileum to carefully flush out the digesta in the gut into a 10 cm diameter Petri-dish (Liu et al., 2007). The digesta from each replicate were pooled and for determination of IDE. Titanium dioxide as an indigestible marker was added at 0.5% to the diets at the beginning of feeding trial and was assayed for using the method of Short et al. (1996). Energy was determined using an Oxygen Bomb Calorimeter (Model 6300, PARR, Moline, IL). The values of AME and IDE will be displayed in kcal/kg and also adjusted for intake as apparent metabolisable energy intake (AMEI) and ileal digestible energy intake (IDEI) (calculated as AMExIntake, kcal). Over the entire period (0-18 d) total FI and BWG (mean per bird per pen) were measured and FCR calculated as FI (kg)/BWG (kg).)
output: {'Planting or Production Trial':['An experiment was conducted at the Henan University of Science and Technology's experimental farm involving 720 Arbor Acres broilers to study the effects of different diets on their growth and nutrient digestibility. The birds were monitored from hatch to 18 days, with various parameters like feed intake and body weight gain measured.']}
